description.narrative: IDH has focused the work of the landscape program on the concept of PPI: Production-Protection-Inclusion. IDH is implementing this concept through the development of PPI compacts in 11 landscapes in seven countries. These are agreements between public, private and civil society parties to enhance sustainable productive land and secure livelihoods in exchange for natural resource conservation. IDH convenes coalitions that develop these compacts. The compacts are based on participatory land-use planning, whereby land for production (increasing productivity), livelihoods (income diversification, resilience, access to markets) and protection (forest, water, soil) is clearly identified, and their related uses are agreed on by the landscape stakeholders and recognized by local and national governments. The compacts also include goals for each of the PPI components, a time-bound plan of action, clear definition of roles and responsibilities, and a budget for implementation. The compacts are the basis for the PPI Fund and other investors to invest in the landscapes, as well as the basis for regional sourcing by supply chain companies. This will result in coalitions that are self-sustaining, are linked to markets, and prove the business case for landscape-level interventions and investments.

receiver-org.narrative: Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

title.narrative: Result Area 1 - Change in business practice
Private sector (sustainability) investments in the program

description.narrative: The actual realized eligible private sector investments per program (in €)

comment.narrative: It will increase thanks to Cargill’s investment in the Cavally forest protection plan.

description.narrative: Qualitative description about the embeddedness of sustainability at corporate level of companies/industry organizations/business platforms (this description should provide information on what have changed over the last reporting period in terms of their approach towards sustainability issues, including responsible sourcing and Protection Production Inclusion criteria in case of the landscapes programs)

comment.narrative: cocoa (traceability) and timber (certification)

title.narrative: Business cases developed within the IDH program to show the potential of sustainable practices

description.narrative: The number and description of business cases that have been developed within the IDH program to demonstrate to the private sector the potential of sustainable practices adopted and implemented by other organizations

comment.narrative: Supporting the transition from full sun, monoculture cocoa to a diversified, forest-friendly, resilient cocoa production model. To this end: agroforestry models have been developed and validated; Social and environmental responsibility committees have been established within communities to sensitize farms’ and coops’ staff and community members; Resource centres will be set up to provide support and planting material for professional nurseries established at coop/community level; Farmers are made aware, trained and coached on GAP and GEP; Financial services are made available for coops and famers to support investments aiming to enhance diversification and increase the resilience of their farm.
At the end of 2020, IDH will develop more qualitative analyses on traceability

title.narrative: IDH participation in relevant landscape and or commodity platforms

description.narrative: The role of IDH landscape programs in relevant platforms, round tables, initiatives and coalitions that are addressing sustainability issues, sector transformation, responsible sourcing etc.

comment.narrative: By 2020, IDH will set up and participate in the activities of the PPI compact in Cavally and Goin-Débé. The 3 platforms we are working on are: 1. Regional ISLA coalition led by IDH, 2. Tree tenure platform led by Impactum, 3. Cocoa & Forests Initiative co-led by IDH and WCF

title.narrative: Representation and commitment of key-stakeholders in multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions

description.narrative: The indicator score is provided by a self-assessment performed by all stakeholders that are involved in the multi-stakeholder processes associated with the program or landscape. On an annual basis, all stakeholders that are active in the processes receive a request to complete a brief electronic questionnaire. The assessment is done through a set of statements focusing on the satisfaction, representation and commitment of the multi-stakeholder processes and coalitions as part of the IDH programs.

comment.narrative: *Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Satisfaction about the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions associated with the program

description.narrative: The perceived satisfaction by the participating stakeholders (i.e. private sector, government, NGOs) of the multi-stakeholder process or coalitions in which they participate.

comment.narrative: *Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Changes at policy and regulatory level contributing to increased sustainability of commodity production and improved management of natural resources

description.narrative: Qualitative description explaining the background and progress of the changes in policies, regulations, and/or enforcement of these as a result of IDH interventions

comment.narrative: 1 SODEFOR has launched the pilot project on improved surveillance of the Cavally forest reserve and on the census of the Goin-Débé forest reserve. Both investments have been endorsed by the national government, further embedding the activities in public-policy development 2 The government of Côte d’Ivoire and the cocoa industry have signed the joint framework of action on cocoa and forests, outlining the actions to be undertaken by industry and government to delink deforestation from cocoa production.
Continuous
No target in 2020

description.narrative: The number and type of landscape plan; qualitative description explaining the background, progress and stage of development or implementation of the plans as a result of the IDH landscape program interventions

comment.narrative: At the time of writing the 2020 annual plan, we had decided to make two landscape plans (around the two classified forests, Goin-Débé and Cavally, individually). In the end, we opted for a single landscape plan for the Cavally region, which takes the two classified forests into account.

title.narrative: Farmland area where trained practices are applied

description.narrative: Number of hectares (ha) of land where trained practices are applied; description of the category of practice applied and type of training/supporting activity implemented

title.narrative: Number of hectares where sustainable production/farm rehabilitation/sustainable intensification are implemented

description.narrative: Number of hectares, type of ecosystem protected (e.g. forest/peatland/grassland), quality of the ecosystem protected (e.g. HCV/HCS area); type of protection and/or restoration activity. It should include as much as possible information on the effectiveness of the protection and restoration measures, i.e. when the statistics are available, add the % of illegal deforestation in the area. This will have to be tracked every year, to measure effectiveness of activities aimed at reducing illegal deforestation in the landscape; for forest restoration activities, track the survival rate of planted seedlings. This will have to be tracked every year, to measure effectiveness of the restoration activity.

comment.narrative: (to reach the 2020 target)
Continuous

title.narrative: Number of trainers, auditors and/or government staff trained in the program

description.narrative: Several programs have indicated they will develop curricula or guidance for service delivery or extension of good practices. This indicator looks at whether this is being achieved, and whether the next step is taken, being the training of trainers and auditors to use these deliverables.

comment.narrative: In this target, we include: a) Start of SRADT’s activities: training heads of decentralized state services in the Cavally region, as well as elected officials (30 people), b) OIPR: training of OIPR agents, prefet and vice-prefet (20 people)

title.narrative: # of producers/workers / community enterprises reached by service delivery

description.narrative: The number of producers/ workers/community enterprises that have been offered services other than training within the scope of the program. These services could be: 1. Input services – planting material, fertilizer, crop protection products/ pesticides. 2. Financial services – inputs on credit, cash advances, pre-harvest finance; 3. Value adding services – services that add value to the product of smallholder farmers, such as mechanization (use of tractors), processing, post-harvest handling and storage services.

comment.narrative: These figures are mainly due to the Wild Chimpanzee Foundation’s theatre tours on the protection of the Cavally forest, which were presented in Abidjan and in all villages in the Taï department. The Wild Chimpanzee Foundation’s theatre tour is seen as an outreach initiative that allows people who have watched the show (or have been affected) to become aware of the importance of protecting Cavally’s forest. This is different from people trained in protection/monitoring such as eco-guards, who are trained to georeference degraded areas, or producers who are trained in agroforestry techniques on their cocoa farms, for example.

title.narrative: # of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues

description.narrative: it is important to capture the following information: The number of producers or workers or community members trained; Split by gender; The number and frequency of individual training events The topic of the training

comment.narrative: Men: 3509, Women: 88
These include farmers trained on GAP and agricultural entrepreneurship done by Barry Callebaut and CÉMOI as well as awareness raising by Barry Callebaut and SODEFOR on forest protection issues.

title.narrative: # of hectares where protection and restoration interventions are implemented (Goin-Débé FC)

description.narrative: The number of hectares covered by protection and restoration interventions.

comment.narrative: Continuous (135,000)
Continuous (135,000)
Continuous (still 135,000 hectares of forest protected)

The actions to be taken in Goin-Débé will depend on the government’s decision. In a new forest code adopted in July 2019, it was decided to reclassify this forest as a “agroforest”. IDH will follow the evolution of the situation in 2020
